content.description: New? slab problem that is only accessible at 'low low' tide on the West (slab) face. A bit spicy, great movement. Line moves directly up through the crystal slash/finger crack straight up the face above. Larger crack to the left and arête to the right are off. Can be reachy at points for shorter climbers. Top out, enjoy the view, and downclimb the larger crack to the left.
content.location: West, slab, face of the Golden boulder. Start standing with both hands on the crystal slash/finger crack in the middle of the face, foot smeared below...large crack to the left, and arête to the right are off. Downclimb the large crack to the left.

content.description: Start standing/squatting with both hands matched on a sloping edge at 5-6 feet. (This will depend a bit on sand levels.) Move right to a sloping crescent shaped sidepull and use it to make a longish move to a good jug. Follow good holds to a tall, but easy, top out.Another amazing line that is well worth the visit. This one really needs to be climbed at absolute low tide or you will be getting your shoes/pads wet. The starting footholds can be a bit wet at times and sand levels influence whether this line is climbable or not.
content.location: This is the furthest route right on the boulder and is located a bit right of the right arete of the beach side face.

content.description:
Start sitting with both hands matched on a large shelf at 3.5 feet. (With low sand levels, this can end up being a stand start.) Flowy moves on good edges and incuts just right of the arete leads to the juggy lip and an easy, but tall, top out.

 A spectacular location, perfect rock, friendly holds and a bit of height make this easily one of the best problems on Long Island. A must do for area climbers.
content.location: This problem climbs the left side of the beach side face, starting just right of the left arete.

content.description:
A stunning highball-ish boulder with three of the best climbs on Long Island.  

  All three of these problems are extremely tide dependent and only climbable at or around low tide. The sand level also tends to vary from year to year, which will have an effect on the height of these problems. Occasionally, the sand level is so low that these boulders aren't climbable at all. So, pay attention to tide charts if you're interested in these lines. 

  As of 10/18, the sand level was perfect!
